Detailed Description

Create Tapi-compliant subscribers with the help of this class, inherits its base functions from Tapi::TapiClient.

Author
Tobias Holst
Version
2.1.1

Member Function Documentation

double * Tapi::Subscriber::AddFeature ( ros::SubscribeOptions  opt,
std::string  featurename = "" 
)

Create a subscriber by adding a feature.

Gets a saved uuid or generates a new one with the help of Tapi::TapiClient. Stores the pair of ros::SubscribeOptions and a pointer to the created ros::Subscriber in the subscribers vector. The SubscriberOptions should be created with the help of the SubscribeOptionsForTapi macro. At last the informations are stored in the Feature-messages vector of Tapi::TapiClient.

Parameters
optOptions to create the subscriber, easiest way is to use SubscribeOptionsForTapi macro
featurenameDescriptive) name of the feature
Returns
Pointer to the coefficient of the connection
See also
Tapi::TapiClient
Tapi::Subscriber::subscribers
Feature.msg
Tapi::Subscriber::coefficients
// Example code to use the Tapi::Subscriber class
// nh is a pointer to a ros::NodeHandle generated outside (e.g. in int main())
Tapi::Subscriber* tsub = new Tapi::Subscriber(nh, "Test");
// Option 1 (longer, but maybe easier to read)
ros::SubscribeOptions opt;
double* coefficient;
// Usage: SubscribeOptionsForTapi(topic_type, queue_length, &callback_function)
opt = SubscribeOptionsForTapi(std_msgs::Float64, 1, &My_Classname::myFloatCallback);
coefficient = tsub->AddFeature(opt, "Double/Float64");
// Option 2 (shorter, but maybe harder to read)
coefficient = tsub->AddFeature(SubscribeOptionsForTapi(std_msgs::Float64, 1, &My_Classname::myFloatCallback),
"Double/Float64");
// In the callback function now don't forget to multiply with the coeffeicient, e.g.:
void My_Classname::myFloatCallback(const std_msgs::Float64::ConstPtr& msg)
{
double value = msg->data * (*coefficient);
// Do something with "value" now
}
// Don't delete \c ros::Subscriber objects, only delete the Tapi::Subscriber object,
// it will shutdown and delete the subscribers in its destructor
delete tsub;

Definition at line 72 of file subscriber.cpp.

void Tapi::Subscriber::readConfigMsg ( const tapi_lib::Connection::ConstPtr &  msg)
private

Get Config-messages from the core to get commands to which Publisher we shall connect.

On this topic all commands about connections are published. So in this function we first have to check if there is one (or more) message with our uuid and a feature uuid of us in it. If yes we check who we shall subscribe/connect or if we have to delete our current connection.

Parameters
msgThe message waiting in the ros message queue where the information about who has to connect to who is stored.
See also
Connection.msg

Definition at line 99 of file subscriber.cpp.

Member Data Documentation

std::vector<double *> Tapi::Subscriber::coefficients
private

coefficients of our subscribers

Stores with which values our received messages have to be multiplied. Only valid for basic number types (e.g std_msgs/Int8, std_msgs/Int16, std_msgs/Float32, ...)

See also
Tapi::Subscriber::readConfigMsg

ros::Subscriber Tapi::Subscriber::configSub
private

Subscriber to subscribe the Config-messages topic to get information of who shall connect to who. Listens on /Tapi/Config.

Definition at line 162 of file subscriber.hpp.

std::vector<std::pair<ros::SubscribeOptions, ros::Subscriber *> > Tapi::Subscriber::subscribers
private

A vector of pair objects of ros::SubscribeOptions and ros::Subscriber to hold the information about all subscribers.

The second part of the pair is zero if the Subscriber isn't connected to a Publisher. If the core tells us to connect, the Subscriber is created with the help of the SubscribeOptions object in the first part of the pair.

See also
Tapi::Subscriber::AddFeature

Definition at line 173 of file subscriber.hpp.

private

vector of current connected topics. This helps to check if we need to change or just stay, if it didn't change.
